intro: Syngonanthus retrorsociliatus, commonly known as the backward-facing sedge, is a species of flowering plant in the family Cyperaceae. It is native to tropical regions of South America, particularly Brazil and Peru. The plant is characterized by its grass-like appearance, with narrow, linear leaves and small, clustered flowers. It typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Syngonanthus retrorsociliatus plays a role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various insects and small animals.
